Title: Aligning Investor Energy with the Field
Overall Purpose: To ensure that investor energy, expectations, and influence reinforce the health, rhythm, and direction of the broader field you serve—not just the needs of the company or portfolio.
Why This Matters: Investors can amplify or distort the energy in a field. Aligning their energy with the field ensures growth benefits the whole ecosystem, not just short-term returns.
When To Use This Protocol:
When selecting investors for a raise
When onboarding new investors
When recalibrating investor relationships
When expanding influence in a mission-driven field

Overall Outcomes.Poor: Investor energy is misaligned with the field → The future sees friction, extraction, and weakened trust in the ecosystem.
Overall Outcomes.Expected: Some alignment exists, but key differences remain unaddressed → The future grows unevenly, with pockets of misfit influence.
Overall Outcomes.Excellent: Investor energy is actively aligned with the field’s health and momentum → The future benefits from amplified impact and trust.
Overall Outcomes.Transcendent: Investor–field alignment is cultural instinct—every investor becomes a steward of the field’s thriving → The future compounds coherence and resilience.

Themes.Name: Understanding the Field’s Energy and Needs
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To deeply understand the current state, needs, and momentum of the field before engaging investors.
Themes.Why This Matters: Without this understanding, investor involvement can unintentionally disrupt healthy dynamics.

Poor.Present pattern: Field context is ignored in investor selection.
Poor.Signals: Investor initiatives clash with field norms.
Poor.Edge condition: You assume company needs are the same as field needs.

Expected.Present pattern: Some understanding of field, but not detailed.
Expected.Signals: Investor asks misaligned with field realities.

Excellent.Present pattern: Clear, detailed understanding of field dynamics.

Transcendent.Edge condition: You refuse investors who resist field alignment.

Guiding Questions: What is the current energy and momentum in the field?
What does the field most need now?
Where could investor influence help or harm?

Themes.Name: Assessing Investor Energy and Intent
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To evaluate the motives, pacing, and influence style of potential investors.
Themes.Why This Matters: Investor energy shapes not just funding but the pace, tone, and priorities of the work.

Poor.Present pattern: Investor motives are unknown or assumed.
Poor.Signals: Pressure to chase trends over field health.

Expected.Present pattern: Some assessment of investor intent, but not holistic.
Expected.Signals: Investor pushes pace misaligned with field rhythm.
Expected.Edge condition: You accept alignment on one dimension only.
Expected.Example moves: Reviewing financial terms without cultural fit check.

Excellent.Present pattern: Full picture of investor intent and energy style understood.
Excellent.Signals: Investor supports agreed pace and priorities.
Excellent.Edge condition: You ensure fit across multiple dimensions.
Excellent.Future effect: Mutual reinforcement of values and outcomes.

Transcendent.Present pattern: Investor energy assessment is cultural instinct.
Transcendent.30-90 day system effect: No tension between investor and field.
Transcendent.Signals: Investor’s influence always amplifies field health.
Transcendent.Edge condition: You refuse investors with misaligned energy.
Transcendent.Example moves: Cultural habit of whole-person investor vetting.

Guiding Questions: What motivates this investor beyond returns?
How does their pace match our field’s rhythm?
What kind of influence do they tend to exert?

Themes.Name: Creating Shared Field Stewardship
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To ensure investors see themselves as co-stewards of the field’s long-term health.
Themes.Why This Matters: Stewardship shifts the relationship from transactional to transformative.

Poor.Present pattern: Investor focus is solely on company ROI.
Poor.Example moves: Never discussing field needs with investors.

Expected.Present pattern: Some discussion of field stewardship, but not embedded.

Excellent.Present pattern: Investor embraces shared field stewardship role.

Transcendent.Present pattern: Field stewardship is cultural instinct among investors.
Transcendent.Signals: Investor advocates for field health even beyond portfolio.
Transcendent.Edge condition: You refuse to work with investors unwilling to steward.

Guiding Questions: How can this investor contribute to the field’s long-term health?
What stewardship commitments can we make together?
How will we track and celebrate field contributions?

Themes.Name: Balancing Company Needs with Field Health
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To make funding and strategy decisions that serve both the company and the field.
Themes.Why This Matters: Company success at the expense of the field undermines long-term viability.

Poor.Example moves: Raising capital for market dominance that harms field.

Expected.Present pattern: Some consideration of field health, but secondary.
Expected.Edge condition: You address field only when convenient.

Excellent.Present pattern: Decisions weigh both company and field outcomes.
Excellent.Signals: Peers see company as contributor to field health.
Excellent.Edge condition: You measure impact on field in all decisions.
Excellent.Future effect: Mutual reinforcement of company and field.

Transcendent.Present pattern: Balance between company and field is cultural instinct.
Transcendent.Signals: Peers seek company leadership in field initiatives.
Transcendent.Edge condition: You reject growth that harms the field.
Transcendent.Future effect: Field and company become inseparable in success.

Guiding Questions: How does this decision impact the field?
Where might company gain and field suffer?

Themes.Name: Embedding Field Alignment in Investor Relationships
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To make field alignment a living, ongoing part of investor engagement.
Themes.Why This Matters: Without regular alignment, investor–field fit can drift over time.

Poor.Present pattern: No ongoing field alignment with investors.
Poor.Edge condition: You treat alignment as one-time exercise.
Poor.Example moves: No review of alignment after onboarding.

Excellent.Present pattern: Regular, structured field alignment with investors.
Excellent.Edge condition: You schedule alignment into investor relations.

Transcendent.Present pattern: Field alignment embedded as cultural instinct.
Transcendent.Edge condition: You protect alignment as a non-negotiable.

Guiding Questions: How will we keep investor and field alignment current?
What cadence will we use for alignment reviews?
What will we do if alignment starts to drift?

Completion Prompts: Capture one commitment to align investor energy with field health.
Name one signal that shows investor and field alignment.
Choose your next smallest move to reinforce field stewardship.

Primary Scenarios: Expanding influence in a mission-driven field
